cohere_generated_answer: The Coriolis force, pressure gradient force, and frictional force all play a significant role in shaping the velocity and direction of wind. The Coriolis force, caused by the Earth's rotation, deflects winds toward the right in the Northern Hemisphere and toward the left in the Southern Hemisphere. This effect is more pronounced at higher latitudes. The pressure gradient force influences both the speed and direction of wind, with wind flowing from areas of high pressure to low pressure. The greater the pressure difference, the stronger the wind velocity. Frictional force, on the other hand, acts to slow down winds as they interact with the Earth's surface, particularly at lower altitudes and over land.
